hobby.message: Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Oh, just another long day. City feels... different lately.
I usually fold origami at home. Simple way to pass time.
Too noisy for it now with all the score chaos outside.
I haven't made anything decent this week.
It's been strange since the mural crowds started gathering.
I fold origami, actually. Used to help me clear my mind.
Lately the noise and arguments at my block throw me off.
Tried to work on some models last night. Couldn't focus.
Guess that calm doesn't last when history unravels on your doorstep.
You know, I make origami—complex stuff, modular stars, tessellations.
Normally it keeps my nerves steady, but the recent BCI chaos ruined that.
People arguing scores all night outside my flat. Difficult to focus.
I tried making a star model yesterday. Gave up halfway through.
Never seen neighbors so worked up over numbers before.
Even the paper feels different now.
Honestly? I spend hours folding origami—used to be meditation for me.
I like challenging designs, the ones that take dozens of precise steps.
It helped after tough reviews at work, until last week’s data release.
Crowds outside, noise, people debating old scores. No quiet for folding now.
Yesterday I botched three cranes. Couldn’t keep my hands steady.
Feels like everyone’s truths are out and nothing is private.
Somehow, even my paper feels implicated.
City’s upside down since the BCI records went public. No quiet spots left.
Origami was my refuge. I’d fold intricate models from old Directorate printouts.
It started as stress relief—something precise in a world of blurry lines.
Now, people pace the halls, arguing over score histories I once processed myself.
Tried to fold a modular star last night—hands shaking, mind spinning.
When I see my own old entries stamped on public terminals, it unsettles me.
Funny, even paper feels compromised—like it carries the city’s secrets.
I haven’t managed a single clean model since everything changed.
hobby_answer: No, nothing new lately.
Hard to focus with everything happening outside.
Paper feels... trivial, honestly.
With all the noise, I stopped folding for now.
Too risky to keep distractions.
Not recently. Tried, but couldn't finish anything.
People outside keep fighting over their data.
The apartment feels different, less private.
Started a crease, but folded it away instead.
Origami needs calm hands—haven't had those since the release.
Maybe soon, if things quiet down.
Haven't made anything new since the archives went public.
I keep thinking about how a wrong fold can't be undone.
The halls outside my place are loud, everyone's talking scores.
Used to relax me, making cranes or kusudama.
Last week, none of my models turned out right.
Errors keep creeping in after those appeals I handled.
Feels strange, using crisp paper when everything's unraveling.
Honestly, I haven't folded at all since the BCI data dropped.
It used to keep me centered—hundreds of shapes memorized.
Now, even the quietest corner's full of arguing neighbors.
I tried the modular star pattern I always liked. Couldn't finish.
People shouting for answers outside kept breaking my focus.
Some want justice for forgotten scores. Others just want scapegoats.
Feels like every crease reminds me of protocols I executed.
I miss when my hands could just move without second-guessing.
No, haven't folded a single model since the data release.
Strange. Origami was my escape—learned as a child, from my grandmother.
Used to spend hours on multi-piece tessellations—pure detail, no mistakes allowed.
Last time I tried, I kept seeing faces from appeals, echoing demands.
I even tore a sheet in frustration. Never did that before.
Now my building's full of neighbors shouting histories at each other.
I can't separate folds from consequences anymore—my mind just loops protocols and regrets.
Even my favorite paper feels complicit in the system.
Maybe someday I'll pick it up again, but it can't just be habit now.
